channel.title: Baosen Zhang
channel.description: Baosen Zhang is an Associate Professor in the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department at the University of Washington.

item.title: The Base Power Company is Looking for Interns
item.description: Two of my former students, Chase Dowling and Daniel Tabas, are looking for interns. Specifically, they are looking for people to design and implementation of sequential decision algorithms for trading energy and ancillary services in the Texas markets. They are great people and I’m sure the problem is interesting! For more information see this job posting.

item.title: We are accepting CEI Distinguished Postdoctoral Fellowship Again
item.description:
The Clean Energy Institute at the University of Washington is now accepting applications for our CEI Distinguished Postdoctoral Fellowship. We invite innovative, exceptionally talented researchers who have recently received their Ph.D. degree (or foreign equivalent) to apply for full-time postdoctoral fellowship positions at the UW’s Seattle campus. The Fellowship is a full-time, 12-month position at the rank of Research Associate. The salary range is $75,000– $100,000 depending on the qualifications and scope of the research proposed by the applicant. Reappointment for an additional year is possible depending upon mutual agreement and funding availability. The Fellowship carries an annual discretionary research budget of $10,000.

Visit the UW CEI website to learn more, or apply directly via Interfolio. If you have any questions, please let me know.

item.title: Recent students and postocs starting their own labs: Wenqi Cui at NYU, Zixiao Ma at Binghamton and Yan Jiang at CUHK.
item.description: Three people from the group at starting their career as Assistant Professors: Wenqi Cui (NYU), Zixiao Ma (Binghamton), and Yan Jiang (CUHK). If you’re a student thinking about where to go for graduate schools, please consider them!

item.title: Three papers in PSCC
item.description:
We have three papers that will appear at the PSCC Conferece:

  1. Y. Jiang, H. Min, and B. Zhang, “Oscillations-Aware Frequency Security Assessment via Efficient Worst-Case Frequency Nadir Computation,” in Power Systems Computation Conference (PSCC), 2024.
    • BibTeX
      • @inproceedings{jiang2024oscillationsaware,
  title = {Oscillations-Aware Frequency Security Assessment via Efficient Worst-Case Frequency Nadir Computation},
  author = {Jiang, Yan and Min, Hancheng and Zhang, Baosen},
  year = {2024},
  booktitle = {Power Systems Computation Conference (PSCC)},
  link = {https://arxiv.org/abs/2402.16765},
  blog = {2024-4-11-PSCC}
}
    • Download
  2. J. Li, M. Motoki, and B. Zhang, “Socially Optimal Energy Usage via Adaptive Pricing,” in Power Systems Computation Conference (PSCC), 2024.

  booktitle = {Power Systems Computation Conference (PSCC)},
  link = {https://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13254},
  blog = {2024-4-11-PSCC}
}
    • Download
  3. J. Stiasny, B. Zhang, and S. Chatzivasileiadis, “PINNSim: A Simulator for Power System Dynamics based on Physics-Informed Neural Networks,” in Power Systems Computation Conference (PSCC), 2024.

item.title: SIGEnergy Rising Star Award
item.description: I’m honored to receive the 2022 SIGEnergy Rising Star Award. For more information, please see https://energy.acm.org/2023/01/31/sigenergy-rising-star-award-2022-winner/

item.title: Paper on Efficient Reinforcement Learning Through Trajectory Generation
item.description: A key barrier to using reinforcement learning (RL) in many real-world applications is the requirement of a large number of system interactions to learn a good control policy. Off-policy and Offline RL methods have been proposed to reduce the number of interactions with the physical environment by learning control policies from historical data. However, their performances suffer from the lack of exploration and the distributional shifts in trajectories once controllers are updated. Moreover, most RL methods require that all states are directly observed, which is difficult to be attained in many settings. To overcome these challenges, we propose a trajectory generation algorithm, which adaptively generates new trajectories as if the system is being operated and explored under the updated control policies. Motivated by the fundamental lemma for linear systems, assuming sufficient excitation, we generate trajectories from linear combinations of historical trajectories. For linear feedback control, we prove that the algorithm generates trajectories with the exact distribution as if they are sampled from the real system using the updated control policy. In particular, the algorithm extends to systems where the states are not directly observed. Experiments show that the proposed method significantly reduces the number of sampled data needed for RL algorithms.
